description: From Latin de- + hiscere (“to split”), from hiare (“to be open”); related to hiatus.

verbs.description: dehisce (third-person singular simple present dehisces, present participle dehiscing, simple past and past participle dehisced)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, botany) To burst or split open at definite places, discharging seeds, pollen or similar content.
examples: Anthers dehisce when the flower opens.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, medicine) To rupture or break open, as a surgical wound.
examples: A surgical wound may partially or completely dehisce after surgery, depending upon whether some or all of the layers of tissue come open.
